work properly. Previously, because of LispWorks limitations, command keystrokes could not
be passed to Boxer. So, a box called command-a-key would only be activated
on pressing control-a-key. I think command keys stilll can't be directly bound. Is that still

set-scroll-row does not work for boxes that have been changed in the interpreter BEFORE YOU
The box "stuff" has a set of numbered rows. The doit box below it adds a new row and tries to set the scroll row to 5. It fails,
and instead just returns the scroll-to row to 1.
If you execute the commands in the doit box one at a time (thus returning to top level BEFORE doing the scroll) all is well.
(It seems that changing a box sets the scroll row back to 1. Not obviously the thing to do, but maybe necessary in the
One rationale NOT to force creating an editor box on the fly is that it
might be expensive. But, scrolling is generally an interface operation
and won't be performed much in the midst of other code, so few people
It's also possible that for some reason you can't create a full editor box
on the fly. I woulodn't know. --Andy

none of the mouse-box commands seem to work
They are supposed to return a port to the box in which the cursor resides.
mouse-box-on-click - returns a port to the next box that you click in. Useful for tools that act
on generic boxer structure, such as selecting data to process with a tool.
mouce-box-on-release - same sort of thing, but the "activate" signal is a relese, not a click.

The two clicker conditions check+ and check- cause
a crash when check-all is executed. I'm guessing this is
because these procedures terminate with by popping the
stack up to check-all, with either true or false as returned values.
True is the value that causes a crash. I don't think false crashes.
(Might be that false does not pop the stack with "stop")

If you have any trouble interpretijng how the clickers work, just ask.
I might be able to easily explain things that are not apparent.
I might also be able to simplify the crash conditions so that you don't
need to understand much about clickers to see what's going on.
Boxer has a way of allowing the user to re-define almost any interface actions,
like pressing a key or doing various kinds of mouse-clicks. You just define a function
with a "magic name," like mouse-click or a-key.  However, all the mouse
redefinitions seem to be broken. They either return a "weird objec" or flatly crash Boxer.
On the other hand, re-defining keystrokes seems to work (except we're still stuck without
proper command- and cntrl- options. At last sight, you had to define command keys using
cntrl- in the name, and you could not define command keys at all. Ed said this was
a LispWorks bug, but surely that must be fixed by now.
I looked at some instances how I used like "mouse-click" and it seems they expected the ordinary
action of a mouse click to be executed. In the case of  "mouse-click",  the cursor should be moved
to where the mouse is clicked.
In any case, these commands ertainly should not crash or return a weird object.
Most seem to just crash when executed, but a few (e.g. MOUSE-CLICK) return some weird object.
COMMAND-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-TOP-RIGHT is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK-ON-BOTTOM-LEFT is a primitive with no arguments
OPTION-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-BOTTOM-RIGHT is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK-ON-SPRITE is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK-ON-SCROLL-BAR is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK-ON-TOP-RIGHT is a primitive with no arguments
COMMAND-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-BOTTOM-LEFT is a primitive with no arguments
OPTION-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-GRAPHICS is a primitive with no arguments
OPTION-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-TOP-LEFT is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK-ON-TOP-LEFT is a primitive with no arguments
MOUSE-CLICK is a primitive with no arguments
COMMAND-MOUSE-CLICK-ON-TOP-LEFT is a primitive with no arguments

The current paste regimin has "paste" separate from "paste from clipboard".
That is, there are to clipboards, one for Boxer clippings and one for outside-of-Boxer
clippings. I'm thinking this is just less converntional, and often complicated than
having a single "paste." Paste-graphics is also a separate action. Offhand, I think it'd
be better to unify all into a sigle paste. Granted it might be technically slightly more compicated
to implement (have to identify graphics in some cut and separately turn them into graphics boxes)
but this doesn't sound hard. I'm open to debate on this.
